text: hi I'm Colleen Camus CHEO I'm from Dow Jones specifically I'm from the customer
data team at Dow Jones and my department is responsible for all of our customer
data across the entire company that includes our customer data from our consumer products like Wall Street
Journal Barron's and market watch it includes all of our customer data for our b2b products like Factiva and risk
and compliance and it also includes data for around our a lot of our advertising propositions that we offer our clients
on Wall Street Journal barons and market watch and our team is responsible for collecting all of that information and
making it available to the rest of the company so exactly two years today we
embarked on an adventure to create a brand new customer data platform we
heard a lot of different things from the folks that we service throughout the business they were having problems
getting the data that they were looking for the data had multiple versions of the truth throughout the company there
was limited visibility into the things they were looking for wasted time trying to find it and they were really
struggling to get to what they needed and our infrastructure that housed our existing enterprise data warehouse was
old its end-of-life and really wasn't able to scale the way that we needed to to keep
up with the business demand and I don't think any of these problems are unique to our company I think everybody here in
the room if you've ever talked to your clients about problems with old architecture that they've had the same
issues so we set out to build a brand
new platform and we really wanted to change the game around how we use data in the company we wanted to more from
being a costs a cost generator and turn into a revenue generator and we really
wanted to be first in class around how people use our data to power their business decisions and our approach was
very interesting because in order to create our environment we decided to create what we called the Environmental
Council we grabbed folks from AWS we grabbed folks from around our company
either folks that worked with data directly or folks that worked with data indirectly and we partnered with a few consultancies to
put together a group of folks who were really smart and really ahead of the game on what our architecture could look
like and from there we created what our platform architecture would look like we
when we set out to really go and build it we didn't want to jump right to the fancy stuff we knew that we needed to

building the platform where we started with just getting everything into one place visualizing it bringing more data

just a place where you can put all of your information but for us a data Lake is more than just a dumping ground for
info for us in order for the information to be valuable to our users throughout the company we wanted to make sure that
the data once it made it into the platform was cleansed that it was formatted that it was labeled that it
was keyed so that it was very easy easily used by our end users and we
could take a lot of that data prep and data cleansing steps out of the entire process and have folks really focus on
the analytics but even though we were in a big data architecture we didn't want to lose sight of some of the more
traditional data warehousing concepts so we did not forget about the idea of a
data Mart for us we thought that even though our users had there had the data
lake available to them but there was still reasons for creating the general concept of a data Mart places where we
knew there was a lot of business rules places where these business rules were constantly applied so if we didn't want
our users to have to consistently put these filters on the data we would create a data Mart and there
were a lot of reasons for creating some additional aggregations that were really valuable to our user so any of those
times where there was business rules aggregation we decided that we would go and set out to build a Mart that would
make the data easily understandable by our users so this looks familiar it's a
standard AWS reference architecture chart and there's a lot of AWS services on here but I want to hone in on the
things that are the most important to us so our data moves from on-premises into
our AWS landing zone our key services on this chart are s3 buckets our s3 buckets
are where we deposit all of our data and we have a very sophisticated bucket strategy that we employ to make sure
that the data is organized in the appropriate way and helps to make sure that data is accessed by the right users
in order to move the data through the different buckets and organize it and cleanse it we're using EMR with SPARC to
do all of the transformation through our landing all the way to our warehouse we
use air flow for orchestration so we've integrated air flow with EMR so that we
can run our jobs on a scheduled basis we're using glue for our catalog and for
making sure that all the table is data is labeled properly and then finally our landing place for all of our data is
redshift and we're using red shift and red shift spectrum to give our users the
ability to query the data so I mentioned
earlier that we didn't completely abandon some of the general ideas around data warehousing so when coming up with
our bucket structure we organize our data in the different areas that you would normally see in a traditional data
warehouse we have our landing area where all the data drops we have our staging
area this is where we do the formatting that transfer to park' and where we do a
lot of our initial labeling and we will do a lot of change data capture in this area that we can make sure that as the data
is changing from day to day that we're capturing all of those changes so we can do historical analysis and do some
really cool things with regression but we also decided that we were going to
make sure that we had clean areas for any place where we wanted to do some warehousing of the data so if we wanted
to apply the concept of data Mart's we also have different buckets for the final transformed areas and then
anything that we want to put as an actual warehouse table in redshift we
have a special area for that within our bucket strategy as well so from a cost perspective everything lives in s3 we
have logs that in our s3 buckets so that we can watch how the data is transformed over time and the the key to querying
this information is in s3 is not really athena but it is actually redshift and
that was a really important decision factor for us we decided to use redshift as our analytical database not because
of its analytical capabilities which are awesome but a lot of it had to do with user permission we are dealing with
customer data and we didn't want to make our data fully available to everybody so
a lot of the permissioning that's available within redshift really met our needs just giving people access to the
s3 buckets wasn't enough within redshift we're able to permission users to
specific schemas or were able to permission them specific tables and were able to create the tables with a
specific structure so that if we needed to hide certain variables like very sensitive customer information we could
do so and with the power of redshift in the power of redshift spectrum we were able to do all that at a low cost
so our redshift instance is actually very small and we utilize the power of glue to make sure that we've defined all
of our tables and done all of that permissioning
here is where we then decided to come up with some of the tools that we were

we have a variety of different areas so we've organized our schema based on customer data content the very first
